Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Opioid-Free Anesthesia in Bariatric Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This single-center, randomized controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care hospital.

Participants.evidence: Participants were morbidly obese patients (BMI > 60 kg/mÂ²) scheduled for laparoscopic gastric bypass.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received OFA with total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) using propofol, lidocaine, ketamine, and dexmedetomidine, while the control group received standard opioid-based anesthesia.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates opioid-free anesthesia (OFA) with multimodal analgesia in morbidly obese patients to minimize respiratory and opioid-related complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain control, measured by the visual analog scale (VAS) over 48 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 100 participants were randomized: 50 to the OFA group and 50 to the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The OFA group had a shorter ICU stay and earlier discharge (mean difference = 2 days, 95% CI 1 to 3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were minimal, with 2% in the OFA group and 5% in the control group experiencing mild side effects.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Institute of Health.
